class="md-article-container container template-large_paginated">            <h1>Military technology</h1><div class="md-byline">	<div class="written-by">			<span>Written By: </span>			<ul>				<li><a href="/contributor/John-F-Guilmartin/3551">John F. Guilmartin</a></li>				</ul>			</div>	<div class="last-updated hidden-xs">			<a data-type="accordion-link" href="#accordion-article-history" rel="nofollow">See Article History</a>			</div>	</div><div class="grid">				<div class="grid-sm">					<article id="article-content" class="content"><section id="ref1" data-level="1"><p><strong><span id="ref521888"></span>Military technology</strong>,  range of weapons, equipment, structures, and vehicles used specifically for the purpose of fighting. It includes the knowledge required to construct such <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/technology" class="md-crosslink autoxref">technology</a>, to employ it in combat, and to repair and replenish it.</p><!--[P1]--><p>The technology of war may be divided into five categories. Offensive arms harm the enemy, while defensive weapons ward off offensive blows. Transportation technology moves soldiers and weaponry; communications coordinate the movements of armed forces; and sensors detect forces and guide weaponry.</p><!--[P2]--><p>From the earliest times, a critical relationship has existed between military technology, the tactics of its employment, and the psychological factors that bind its users into units. Success in combat, the sine qua non of military organizations and the ultimate purpose of military technology, depends on the ability of the combatant group to coordinate the actions of its members in a tactically effective manner. This coordination is a function of the strength of the forces that bind the unit together, inducing its members to set aside their individual interests—even life itself—for the welfare of the group. These forces, in turn, are directly affected both by tactics and by technology.</p><!--[P3]--><p>The influence of technology can be either positive or negative. The experience of the ancient Greek <span id="ref521889"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/hoplite" class="md-crosslink">hoplite</a> infantrymen is one example of positive influence. Their arms and armour were most effective for fighting in close formation, which led in turn to marching in step, which further augmented cohesion and made the phalanx a tactically <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/formidable" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="formidable">formidable</a> formation. The late <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/medieval" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="medieval">medieval</a> <span id="ref521890"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/knight-cavalryman" class="md-crosslink">knight</a> offers an example of the negative influence of technology. To wield his sword and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/lance-weapon" class="md-crosslink autoxref">lance</a> effectively, he and his charger needed considerable space, yet his closed helmet made communication with his fellows extremely difficult. It is not surprising, then, that knights of the late Middle Ages tended to fight as individuals and were often defeated by <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/cohesive" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="cohesive">cohesive</a> units of less well-equipped opponents.</p><!--[P4]--><p>This article traces the development of military technology by historical period, from prehistory to the 18th century. For a discussion of modern military technology, see <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/small-arm" class="md-crosslink">small arm</a>, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/artillery" class="md-crosslink">artillery</a>, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/rocket-and-missile-system" class="md-crosslink">rocket and missile system</a>, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/nuclear-weapon" class="md-crosslink">nuclear weapon</a>, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/chemical-weapon" class="md-crosslink">chemical warfare</a>, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/biological-weapon" class="md-crosslink">biological warfare</a>, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/fortification" class="md-crosslink">fortification</a>, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/tank-military-vehicle" class="md-crosslink">tank</a>, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/naval-ship" class="md-crosslink">naval ship</a>, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/submarine-naval-vessel" class="md-crosslink">submarine</a>, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/military-aircraft" class="md-crosslink">military aircraft</a>, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/warning-system" class="md-crosslink">warning system</a>, and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/military-communication" class="md-crosslink">military communication</a>.</p><!--[P5]--><p>A general treatment of the actual waging of war is found in <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/war" class="md-crosslink">war</a>, with more specific discussions appearing in such articles as <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/strategy-military" class="md-crosslink">strategy</a>, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/tactics" class="md-crosslink">tactics</a>, and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/logistics-business" class="md-crosslink">logistics</a>. The social sciences of war, such as economics, law, and the theory of its origins, are also covered in that article. For a military history of World Wars I and II, see <a href="https://www.britannica.com/event/World-War-I" class="md-crosslink">World War I</a> and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/event/World-War-II" class="md-crosslink">World War II</a>.</p><!--[P6]--><p>Warfare requires the use of technologies that also have nonmilitary applications. For descriptions of the propulsion systems used in military vehicles, ships, aircraft, and missiles, see <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/energy-conversion" class="md-crosslink">energy conversion</a>; for the manufacture of explosives, see <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/explosive" class="md-crosslink">explosives</a>. The principles of radar, and its military applications, are covered in <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/radar" class="md-crosslink">radar</a>. For the principles of aircraft flight, see airplane.</p><!--[P7]--></section><span class="md-signature"><a href="/contributor/John-F-Guilmartin/3551">John F. Guilmartin</a></span><div class="major-reference-upsell">			<iframe src="/GPTIframe/ajax/sync/EB_HOUSE_DESKTOP" scrolling="no" width="640" height="106"></iframe>		</div><section id="ref57559" data-level="1"><h2 class="h1">General considerations</h2><p>In the remote past, the <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/diffusion" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="diffusion">diffusion</a> of military technology was gradual and uneven. There were several reasons for this. First, transport was slow and its capacity small. Second, the technology of agriculture was no more advanced than that of war, so that, with most of their energy devoted to feeding themselves and with little economic surplus, people had few resources available for specialized military technology. Low economic development meant that even the benefits of conquest would not pay off a heavy investment in weaponry. Third, and most important, the absolute level of technological development was low. A heavy dependence on human muscle was the principal cause and a major effect of this low level of development. With human ingenuity bound by the constraints of the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/human-body" class="md-crosslink autoxref">human body</a>, both technology and tactics were heavily shaped by geography, climate, and <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/topography" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="topography">topography</a>.</p><!--[P8]--><p>The importance of geographic and topographic factors, along with limited means of communication and transportation, meant that separate geographic regions tended to develop unique military technologies. Such areas are called <span id="ref521891"></span>military ecospheres. The boundaries of a military ecosphere might be physical barriers, such as oceans or mountain ranges; they might also be changes in the military topography, that combination of terrain, vegetation, and man-made features that could render a particular technology or tactic effective or ineffective.</p><!--[P9]--><p>Until the late 15th century <span class="text-smallcaps">ad</span>, when advances in transportation technology broke down the barriers between them, the world contained a number of military ecospheres. The most clearly defined of these were based in Mesoamerica, Japan, India–Southeast Asia, China, and Europe. (In this <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/context" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="context">context</a>, Europe includes all of the Mediterranean basin and the watershed of the Tigris and Euphrates rivers.) With the appearance of the horse archer in late antiquity, the Eurasian Steppe became a well-defined military ecosphere as well.</p><!--[P10]--><p>Those ecospheres with the most enduring impact on the technology of war were the European and Chinese. Though Japan possessed a distinctive, <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/coherent" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="coherent">coherent</a>, and effective military technology, it had little influence on developments elsewhere. India–Southeast Asia and Mesoamerica developed technologies that were well adapted to local conditions, but they were not particularly advanced. The <span id="ref521892"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/the-Steppe" class="md-crosslink">Eurasian Steppe</a> was a special case: usually serving as an avenue for a limited exchange of knowledge between Europe and China, in the late classical and medieval eras of Europe it developed an <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/indigenous" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="indigenous">indigenous</a> military technology based on the horse and composite recurved bow that challenged Europe and ultimately conquered China.</p><!--[P11]--><p>Improved methods of transportation and warfare led to the eventual disappearance of the regional ecospheres and their absorption into the European ecosphere. This process began in the 12th century with the Mongol conquest of China and invasions of Europe, and it quickened and assumed a more pronounced European flavour in the 15th and 16th centuries with the development of oceangoing ships armed with <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/gunpowder" class="md-crosslink autoxref">gunpowder</a> weapons.</p><!--[P12]--><p>Because European methods of warfare ultimately dominated the world, and because the technology of war, with few exceptions, advanced first and fastest in Europe, this article devotes most of its attention to the European military ecosphere. It traces the technology of land war in that ecosphere from <a href="https://www.britannica.com/event/Stone-Age" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Stone Age</a> weapons to the early guns. For reasons of <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/continuity" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="continuity">continuity</a>, warships from before the gunpowder era are discussed with modern naval ships and craft in the article <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/naval-ship" class="md-crosslink">naval ship</a>.</p><!--[P13]--></section><!--[H3]--><section id="ref57560" data-level="1"><h2 class="h1">Prehistory</h2><section id="ref57561" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2">The earliest military <span id="ref521893"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/weapon" class="md-crosslink">weapons</a></h2><p>The earliest evidence for a specialized technology of war dates from the period before knowledge of metalworking had been acquired. The stone <span id="ref521894"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/walls-of-Jericho" class="md-crosslink">walls of Jericho</a>, which date from about 8000 <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span>, represent the first technology that can be ascribed unequivocally to purely military purposes. These walls, at least 13 feet (4 metres) in height and backed by a watchtower or redoubt some 28 feet tall, were clearly intended to protect the settlement and its <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/water-supply" class="md-crosslink autoxref">water supply</a> from human intruders.</p><!--[P14]--><p>When the defenses of Jericho were built, humans already had been using the weapons of the hunt for millennia; the earliest stone tools are hundreds of thousands of years old, and the first arrowheads date to more than 60,000 years ago. Hunting tools—the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/spear-thrower" class="md-crosslink autoxref">spear-thrower</a> (atlatl), the simple bow, the javelin, and the sling—had serious military potential, but the first known <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/implements" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="implements">implements</a> designed purposely as offensive weapons were <span id="ref521895"></span>maces dating from the Chalcolithic Period or early <a href="https://www.britannica.com/event/Bronze-Age" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Bronze Age</a>. The mace was a simple rock, shaped for the hand and intended to smash bone and flesh, to which a handle had been added to increase the velocity and force of the blow.</p><!--[P15]--><p>It is evident that the technical problems of hafting a stone onto a handle were not easily solved. Well-made maces were for a long time few in number and were, by and large, wielded only by champions and rulers. The earliest known inscription identifying a historical personage by name is on the palette of King Narmer, a small, low-relief slate sculpture dating from about 3100 <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span>. The palette depicts Menes, the first pharaoh of a unified Egypt, ritually smashing the forehead of an enemy with a mace.</p><!--[P16]--><p>The advent of the mace as a purposely designed offensive weapon opened the door to the conscious <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/innovation" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="innovation">innovation</a> of specialized military technology. By the middle of the 3rd millennium <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span>, mace heads were being cast of copper, first in Mesopotamia and then in Syria, Palestine, and Egypt. The copper mace head, yielding higher density and greater crushing <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/power-physics" class="md-crosslink autoxref">power</a>, represents one of the earliest significant uses of metal for other than ornamental purposes.</p><!--[P17]--></section><section id="ref57562" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2">From precious metals to base metals</h2><p>The dividing line between the utilitarian and the symbolic in warfare has never been clear and <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/unequivocal" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="unequivocal">unequivocal</a>, and this line is particularly difficult to find in the design and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/construction-technology" class="md-crosslink autoxref">construction</a> of early weaponry. The <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/engineering" class="md-crosslink autoxref">engineering</a> principles that dictated functional effectiveness were not understood in any systematic fashion, yet the psychological reality of victory or defeat was starkly evident. The result was an “unscientific” approach to warfare and technology, in which materials appear to have been applied to military purposes as much for their presumed mystical or magical properties as for their functional worth.</p><!--[P18]--><p>This overlapping of symbolism and usefulness is most evident in the smith’s choice of materials. Ornaments and ceremonial <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/artifacts" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="artifacts">artifacts</a> aside, metalworking was applied to the production of weaponry as early as, or earlier than, any other economically significant pursuit. <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/Precious" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="Precious">Precious</a> metals, with their low melting points and great malleability, were worked first; next came copper—at first pure, then alloyed with arsenic or tin to produce bronze—and then iron. A remarkable phenomenon was the persistence of weaponry made of the soft, rare metals such as gold, silver, and electrum (a naturally occurring alloy of gold and silver) long after mechanically superior materials had become available. Although they were functionally inferior to bronze or copper, precious metals were widely valued for their mystical or symbolic importance, and smiths continued to make weapons of them long after they had mastered the working of functionally superior base metals. Some of these weapons were plainly ceremonial, but in other cases they appear to have been functional. For example, helmets and body armour of electrum, which were probably intended for actual use, have been found in Egyptian and Mesopotamian burials dating from the 2nd and 3rd millennia <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span>.</p><!--[P19]--></section></section><!--[H4]--><section id="ref57563" data-level="1"><h2 class="h1">Antiquity and the classical age, <em>c.</em> 1000 <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span>–<span class="text-smallcaps">ad</span> 400</h2><p>From the appearance of iron weaponry in quantity during late antiquity until the fall of Rome, the means with which war was waged and the manner in which it was conducted displayed many enduring characteristics that gave the period surprising unity. Prominent features of that unity were a continuity in the design of individual weaponry, a relative lack of change in transportation technology, and an enduring tactical dominance of heavy infantry.</p><!--[P20]--><p>Perhaps the strongest underlying technological feature of the period was the heavy reliance on human muscle, which retained a tactical primacy that contrasted starkly with medieval times, when the application of horse power became a prime ingredient of victory. (There were two major, if partial, exceptions to this prevailing feature: the success of horse archers in the great Eurasian Steppe during late classical times, and the decisive use in the 4th century <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span> of <span id="ref521896"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/shock-cavalry" class="md-crosslink">shock cavalry</a> by the armies of Philip II of <span id="ref521898"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Macedonia-ancient-kingdom-Europe" class="md-crosslink">Macedon</a> and his son <a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Alexander-the-Great" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Alexander the Great</a>. However, the defeat of Roman legions by Parthian horse archers at Carrhae in western Mesopotamia in 53 <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span> marked merely a shifting of boundaries between ecospheres on topographical grounds rather than any fundamental change within the core of the European ecosphere itself. Also, the <span id="ref521897"></span>shock cavalry of Philip and Alexander was an exception so rare as to prove the rule; moreover, their decisiveness was made possible by the power of the Macedonian infantry phalanx.) Heavy infantry remained the dominant European military institution until it was overthrown in the 4th century <span class="text-smallcaps">ad</span> by a system of war in which shock cavalry played the central role.</p><!--[P21]--><p>Classical technologists never developed an efficient means of applying <span id="ref521899"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/military-transportation" class="md-crosslink">animal traction</a> to haulage on land, no doubt because agricultural resources in even the most advanced areas were incapable of supporting meaningful numbers of horses powerful enough to make the effort worthwhile. Carts were heavy and easily broken, and the throat-and-girth harness for horses, mules, and donkeys put pressure on the animals’ windpipes and neck veins, severely restricting the amount they could pull. The yoke-and-pole harness for oxen was relatively efficient and oxen could pull heavy loads, but they were extremely slow. A human porter, on the other hand, was just as efficient as a pack horse in weight carried per unit of food consumed. The best recipe for mobility, therefore, was to restrict pack animals to the minimum needed for carrying bulky items such as essential rations, tents, and firewood, to use carts only for items such as siege engines that could be carried in no other way, and to require soldiers to carry all their personal equipment and some of their food.</p><!--[P22]--><p>On the other hand, mastery of wood and bronze for military purposes reached a level during this period that was seldom, if ever, attained afterward. Surviving patterns for the Roman military boot, the caliga, suggest equally high standards of craftsmanship in leatherworking, and the standards of carpentry displayed on classical ships were almost impossibly high when measured against those of later eras.</p><!--[P23]--><section id="ref57564" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2"><span id="ref521900"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/armour-protective-clothing" class="md-crosslink">Defensive weaponry</a></h2><p>The design and production of individual defensive equipment was restricted by the shape of the human form that it had to protect; at the same time, it placed heavy demands on the smith’s skills. The large areas to be protected, restrictions on the weight that a combatant could carry, the difficulty of forging metal into the complex <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/contours" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="contours">contours</a> required, and cost all conspired to force constant change.</p><!--[P24]--><p>The technology of defensive weapons was rarely static. Evidence exists of an ancient contest between offensive and defensive weaponry, with defensive weaponry at first leading the way. By 3000 <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span> Mesopotamian smiths had learned to craft helmets of copper-and-arsenic bronze, which, no doubt worn with a well-padded leather lining, largely neutralized the offensive advantages of the mace. By 2500 <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span> the Sumerians were making helmets of bronze, along with bronze spearheads and ax blades. The weapon smiths’ initial response to the helmet was to augment the crushing power of the mace by casting the head in an ellipsoidal form that concentrated more force at the point of impact. Then, as technical competence increased, the ellipsoidal head became a cutting edge, and by this process the mace evolved into the ax. The contest between mace and helmet initiated a contest between offensive and defensive technology that continued throughout history.</p><!--[P25]--><span id="ref57564" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref57565" data-level="3"><h2 class="h3"><span id="ref521901"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/helmet-armour" class="md-crosslink">Helmets</a></h2><p>The helmet, though arguably the earliest focus of the armourer’s craft, was one of the most demanding challenges. Forging an <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/integral" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="integral">integral</a>, one-piece dome of metal capable of covering the entire head was extremely difficult. The Corinthian Greek helmet, a deep, bowl-shaped helmet of carefully graduated thickness forged from a single piece of bronze, probably represented the functional as well as <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/aesthetic" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="aesthetic">aesthetic</a> apex of the bronze worker’s art. Many classical Greek helmets of bronze were joined by a seam down the crown.</p><!--[P26]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="146716"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/99/135299-004-B36FAAD0.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/99/135299-004-B36FAAD0.jpg" alt="Corinthian-style helmet" data-width="303" data-height="450"></div></div><figcaption><strong class="md-assembly-title">Corinthian-style helmet</strong><span class="md-assembly-caption">Corinthian-style helmet, bronze, Greek, <em>c.</em> 600–575 <span class="text-smallcaps">bce</span>; in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York City.</span><cite>Photograph by Stephen Sandoval. The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York City, Dodge Fund, 1955 (55.11.10)</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML26]--><p>Iron helmets followed the evolution of iron mail, itself a sophisticated and relatively late development. The legionnaire of the early Roman Republic wore a helmet of bronze, while his successor in the Empire of the 1st century <span class="text-smallcaps">ad</span> wore one of iron.</p><!--[P27]--></section><span id="ref57564" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref57566" data-level="3"><h2 class="h3"><span id="ref521902"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/shield-armour" class="md-crosslink">Shields</a></h2><p>Shields were used for hunting long before they were used for warfare, partly for defense and partly for concealment in stalking game, and it is likely that the military shield evolved from that of the hunter and herdsman. The size and <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/composition" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="composition">composition</a> of shields varied greatly, depending on the tactical demands of the user. In general, the more effective the protection afforded by body armour, the smaller the shield; similarly, the longer the reach of the soldier’s weapon, the smaller his shield. The Greek hoplite, a heavy infantryman who fought in closely packed formation, acquired his name from the <em><span id="ref521903"></span>hoplon</em>, a convex, circular shield, approximately three feet (90 centimetres) in diameter, made of composite wood and bronze. It was carried on the left arm by means of a bronze strap that passed across the forearm and a rope looped around the inner rim with sufficient slack to be gripped in the fist. In the 4th century <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span> the soldier of the Roman Republic, who fought primarily with the spear, carried an oval shield, while the later imperial legionnaire, who closed in with a short sword, protected himself with the <em>scutum</em>, a large cylindrical shield of leather-clad wood that covered most of his body.</p><!--[P28]--></section><span id="ref57564" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref57567" data-level="3"><h2 class="h3">Body armour</h2><p>Padded garments, and perhaps armour of hardened leather, preceded edged metal weapons. It was then a logical, if expensive, step to cast or forge small metal plates and sew them onto a protective <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/dress-clothing" class="md-crosslink autoxref">garment</a>. These provided real protection against arrow, spear, or mace, and the small scales, perforated for attachment, were a far less demanding technical challenge than even the simplest helmet. Armour of overlapping scales of bronze, laced together or sewn onto a backing of padded fabric, is well represented in pictorial evidence and burial items from Mesopotamia, Palestine, and Egypt from about 1500 <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span>, though its use was probably restricted to a small elite.</p><!--[P29]--><span id="ref57564" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref57568" data-level="4"><h2 class="h4"><span id="ref521904"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/bronze-alloy" class="md-crosslink">Bronze</a></h2><p>By classical times, breastplates of bronze, at first beaten and then cast to the warrior’s individual shape, were commonplace among heavy infantry and elite cavalry. Greaves, defenses for the lower leg, closely followed the breastplate. At first these were forged of bronze plates; some classical Greek examples were cast to such fine tolerances that they sprang open and could be snapped onto the calf. Defenses for more remote portions of the body, such as vambraces for the forearm and defenses for the ankle resembling spats, were included in Greek temple dedications, but they were probably not common in field service.</p><!--[P30]--><p>Bronze was the most common metal for body defenses well into the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/event/Iron-Age" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Iron Age</a>, a consequence of the fact that it could be worked in large pieces without extended hand forging and careful tempering, while iron had to be forged from relatively small billets.</p><!--[P31]--></section><span id="ref57564" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref57569" data-level="4"><h2 class="h4"><span id="ref521905"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/chain-mail" class="md-crosslink">Mail</a></h2><p>The first practical body armour of iron was mail, which made its appearance in Hellenistic times but became common only during the Roman Imperial period. (Bronze mail was impractical because of the insufficient strength of the alloy.) Mail, or chain mail, was made of small rings of iron, typically of one-half-inch diameter or less, linked into a protective fabric. The rings were fastened together in patterns of varying complexity depending on the degree of protection desired; in general, smaller, lighter rings fastened in dense, overlapping patterns meant lighter, better protection. The fabrication of mail was extremely labour-intensive. The earliest mail was made of hand-forged links, each individual link riveted together. Later, armourers used punches of hardened iron to cut rings from sheets: this reduced the labour involved and, hence, the cost.</p><!--[P32]--><p>The earliest evidence of mail is depicted on Greek sculpture and friezes dating from the 3rd century <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span>, though this kind of protection might be considerably older (there was some evidence that it might be of Celtic origin). Little else is known about the use of mail by the Greeks, but the Roman legionnaire was equipped with a <em><span id="ref521906"></span>lorica hamata</em>, a mail shirt, from a very early date. Mail was extremely flexible and provided good protection against cutting and piercing weapons. Its main disadvantage was its weight, which tended to hang from the shoulders and waist. In addition, strips of mail tended to curl at the edges; the Romans solved this problem by lacing mail shoulder defenses to leather plates. In the 1st century <span class="text-smallcaps">ad</span> the legionnaire’s mail shirt gave way to a segmented iron torso defense, the <em><span id="ref521907"></span>lorica segmentata</em>.</p><!--[P33]--></section><span id="ref57564" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref57570" data-level="4"><h2 class="h4"><span id="ref521908"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/plate-armour" class="md-crosslink">Plate-iron armour</a></h2><p>While some early forged bronze armour was technically plate, the introduction of the <em>lorica segmentata</em> heralded the production of practical plate armour on a large scale. In general, the term plate would imply a uniform thickness of metal, and only iron could provide reasonably effective protection with uniform thickness without excessive weight.</p><!--[P34]--><p>While the Republican legionnaire’s <em>lorica hamata</em> hung to the midthigh, his imperial successor’s <em>lorica segmentata</em> covered only the shoulders and torso. On the whole, classical plate armour probably provided better protection against smashing and heavy piercing blows, while a shirt of well-made mail covered more of the body and, hence, afforded better protection against slashing blows and missiles.</p><!--[P35]--></section></section></section><section id="ref57571" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2">Offensive weaponry</h2><p>Development of the offensive technology of war was not as constrained by technological and economic limitations as was defensive weaponry. Every significant offensive weapon was widely available, while defensive equipment of high quality was almost always confined to the elite. Perhaps as a consequence, a wide variety of individual offensive weapons appeared in antiquity. One of the most striking facets of ancient military technology is the early date by which individual weapons attained their form and the longevity of early offensive weapons concepts. Some of the weapons of antiquity disappeared as practical military implements in classical and medieval times, and all underwent modification, but, with the exception of the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/halberd" class="md-crosslink autoxref">halberd</a> and crossbow, virtually every significant pre-gunpowder weapon was known in antiquity.</p><!--[P36]--><span id="ref57571" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref57572" data-level="3"><h2 class="h3">The <span id="ref521909"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/ax" class="md-crosslink">ax</a></h2><p>Limitations on the strength of bronze and difficulties in casting and <span id="ref521910"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/hafting" class="md-crosslink">hafting</a> restricted the ax at first to a relatively broad blade mortised into a handle at three points and secured with bindings or rivets. The hafting problem became <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/acute" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="acute">acute</a> as improvements in armour dictated longer, narrower blades designed primarily for piercing rather than cutting. This led to the development of socketed axes, in which the handle passed through a tubular hole cast in the ax head; both hole and head were tapered from front to rear to prevent the head from flying off. This far stronger hafting technique must have been accompanied by a significant improvement in the quality of the metal itself. The pace and timing of these developments varied enormously from place to place, depending on the local level of technology. Sumerian smiths were casting socketed ax heads with narrow piercing blades by 2500 <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span>, while simple mortise-and-tenon hafting was still being used in Egypt 1,000 years later.</p><!--[P37]--></section><span id="ref57571" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref57573" data-level="3"><h2 class="h3">The <span id="ref521911"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/spear-weapon" class="md-crosslink">spear</a></h2><p>Though early man probably employed spears of fire-hardened wood, spearheads of knapped stone were used long before the emergence of any distinction between hunting and military weapons. Bronze spearheads closely followed the development of alloys hard enough to keep a cutting edge and represented, with the piercing ax, the earliest significant military application of bronze. Spearheads were also among the earliest militarily significant applications of iron, no doubt because existing patterns could be directly <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/extrapolated" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="extrapolated">extrapolated</a> from bronze to iron. Though the hafting is quite different, bronze Sumerian spearheads of the 3rd millennium <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span> differ only marginally in shape from the leaf-shaped spearheads of classical <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Greece" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Greece</a>.</p><!--[P38]--><p>The spears of antiquity were relatively short, commonly less than the height of the warrior, and typically were wielded with one hand. As defensive armour and other weapons of shock combat (notably the sword) improved, spear shafts were made longer and the use of the spear became more specialized. The Greek hoplite’s spear was about nine feet long; the Macedonian <em>sarissa</em> was twice that length in the period of Alexander’s conquests and it grew to some 21 feet in Hellenistic times.</p><!--[P39]--></section><span id="ref57571" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref57574" data-level="3"><h2 class="h3">The <span id="ref521912"></span>javelin</h2><p>Javelins, or throwing spears, were shorter and lighter than spears designed for shock combat and had smaller heads. The distinction between javelin and spear was slow to develop, but by classical times the heavy spear was clearly distinguished from the javelin, and specialized javelin troops were commonly used for skirmishing. A throwing string was sometimes looped around the shaft and tied to the thrower’s finger to impart spin to the javelin on release. This improved the weapon’s accuracy and probably increased the range and penetrating power by permitting a harder cast.</p><!--[P40]--><p>A significant refinement of the javelin was the Roman pilum. The pilum was relatively short, about five feet long, and had a heavy head of soft iron that made up nearly one-third of the weapon’s total length. The weight of this weapon restricted its range but gave it greater impact. Its head of soft iron was intended to bend on impact, preventing an enemy from throwing it back.</p><!--[P41]--><p>Like the spear, the javelin was relatively unaffected by the appearance of iron and retained its characteristic form until it was finally abandoned as a serious weapon in the 16th century.</p><!--[P42]--></section><span id="ref57571" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref57575" data-level="3"><h2 class="h3">The <span id="ref521913"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/sling" class="md-crosslink">sling</a></h2><p>The sling was the simplest of the missile weapons of antiquity in principle and the most difficult in practice. It consisted of two cords or thongs fastened to a pouch. A small stone was placed in the pouch, and the slinger whirled the whole affair around to build up velocity before letting go of one of the cord ends to release the projectile. While considerable velocity could be imparted to a projectile in this way, the geometry of the scheme dictated that the release be timed with uncanny precision to achieve even <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/rudimentary" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="rudimentary">rudimentary</a> accuracy. Almost always wielded by tribal or regionally recruited specialists who acquired their skills in youth, the sling featured prominently in warfare in antiquity and classical times. It outranged the javelin and even—at least at some times and places—the bow (a point confirmed in the 4th century <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span> by the Greek historian Xenophon). By classical times, lead bullets, often with slogans or epigrams cast into them—“A nasty present!”—were used as projectiles.</p><!--[P43]--><p>The sling vanished as a weapon of war in the Old World by the end of the classical period, owing mainly to the disappearance of the tribal <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/cultures" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="cultures">cultures</a> in which it originated. (In the New World, on the other hand, both the Aztecs and Incas used the sling with great effect against Spanish conquistadores in the 16th century.)</p><!--[P44]--></section><span id="ref57571" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref57576" data-level="3"><h2 class="h3">The <span id="ref521914"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/sword" class="md-crosslink">sword</a></h2><p>The advantages of a long, sharp blade had to await advanced smelting and casting technology before they could be realized. By about 1500 <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span> the cutting ax had evolved into the sickle sword, a bronze sword with a curved, concave blade and a straight, thickened handle. Bronze swords with straight blades more than three feet long have been found in Greek grave sites; however, because this length exceeded the structural capabilities of bronze, these swords were not practical weapons. As a serious military <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/implement" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="implement">implement</a>, the sword had to await the development of iron forging, and the first true swords date from about 1200 <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span>.</p><!--[P45]--><p>Swords in antiquity and classical times tended to be relatively short, at first because they were made of bronze and later because they were rarely called upon to penetrate iron armour. The blade of the classic Roman stabbing sword, the <em><span id="ref521915"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/gladius" class="md-crosslink">gladius</a></em>, was only some two feet long, though in the twilight years of the empire the <em>gladius</em> gave way to the spatha, the long slashing sword of the barbarians.</p><!--[P46]--></section><span id="ref57571" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref57577" data-level="3"><h2 class="h3">The <span id="ref521916"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/bow-and-arrow" class="md-crosslink">bow</a></h2><p>The bow was simple in concept, yet it represented an extremely sophisticated technology. In its most basic form, the bow consisted of a stave of wood slightly bent by the tension of a bowstring connecting its two ends. The bow stored the force of the archer’s draw as <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/potential-energy" class="md-crosslink autoxref">potential energy</a>, then transferred it to the bowstring as <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/kinetic-energy" class="md-crosslink autoxref">kinetic energy</a>, imparting velocity and killing power to the arrow. The bow could store no more energy than the archer was capable of producing in a single movement of the muscles of his back and arms, but it released the stored energy at a higher velocity, thus overcoming the arm’s <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/inherent" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="inherent">inherent</a> limitations.</p><!--[P47]--><p>Though not as evident, the sophistication of arrow technology matched that of the bow. The effectiveness of the bow depended on the arrow’s <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/efficiency" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="efficiency">efficiency</a> in retaining kinetic energy throughout its trajectory and then transforming it into killing power on impact. This was not a simple problem, as it depended on the mass, aerodynamic drag, and stability of the arrow and on the hardness and shape of the head. These factors were related to one another and to the characteristics of the bow in a complex calculus. The most important variables in this calculus were arrow weight and the length and stiffness of the bow.</p><!--[P48]--><p>Assuming the same length of draw and available force, the total amount of potential energy that an archer could store in a bow was a function of the bow’s length; that is, the longer the arms of the bow, the more energy stored per unit of work expended in the draw and, therefore, the more kinetic energy imparted to the string and arrow. The disadvantage of a long bow was that the stored energy had to serve not only to drive the string and arrow but also to accelerate the mass of the bow itself. Because the longer bow’s more massive arms accelerated more slowly, a longer bow imparted kinetic energy to the string and arrow at a lower velocity. A shorter bow, on the other hand, stored less energy for the same amount of work expended in the draw, but it compensated for this through its ability to transmit the energy to the arrow at a higher velocity. In sum, the shorter bow imparted less total energy to the arrow, but it did so at a higher velocity. Therefore, in practice maximum range was attained by a short, stiff bow shooting a very light arrow, and maximum killing power at medium ranges was attained by a long bow driving a relatively heavy arrow.</p><!--[P49]--><span id="ref57571" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref57578" data-level="4"><h2 class="h4">The early bow</h2><p>The simple bow, made from a single piece of wood, was known to Neolithic hunters; it is clearly depicted in cave paintings of 30,000 <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span> and earlier. The first improvement was the reflex bow, a bow that was curved forward, or reflexively, near its centre so that the string lay close against the grip before the bow was drawn. This increased the effective length of the draw since it began farther forward, close to the archer’s left hand.</p><!--[P50]--></section><span id="ref57571" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref57579" data-level="4"><h2 class="h4">The <span id="ref521917"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/composite-bow" class="md-crosslink">composite recurved bow</a></h2><p>The next major improvement, one that was to remain preeminent among missile weapons until well into the modern era, was the composite recurved bow. This development overcame the inherent limitations of wood in stiffness and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/tensile-strength" class="md-crosslink autoxref">tensile strength</a>. The composite bow’s resistance to bending was increased by reinforcing the rear, or belly, of the bow with horn; its speed and power in recoil were increased by overlaying the front of the bow with sinew, usually applied under tension. The wooden structure of this composite thus consisted of little more than thin wooden strips supporting the horn and sinew. The more powerful composite bows, being very highly stressed, reversed their curvature when unstrung. They acquired the name recurved since the outer arms of the bow curved away from the archer when the bow was strung, which imparted a <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/mechanical-advantage" class="md-crosslink autoxref">mechanical advantage</a> at the end of the draw. Monumental and artistic evidence suggest that the principle of the composite recurved bow was known as early as 3000 <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span>.</p><!--[P51]--><p>A prime advantage of the composite bow was that it could be engineered to essentially any desired strength. By following the elaborate but empirically understood trade-off between length and stiffness referred to above, the bowyer could produce a short bow capable of propelling light arrows to long ranges, a long, heavy bow designed to maximize penetrative power at relatively short ranges, or any desired compromise between.</p><!--[P52]--></section><span id="ref57571" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref57580" data-level="4"><h2 class="h4">Arrows</h2><p>Arrow design was probably the first area of military technology in which production considerations assumed overriding importance. As a semi-expendable munition that was used in quantity, arrows could not be evaluated solely by their technological effectiveness; production costs had to be considered as well. As a consequence, the materials used for arrowheads tended to be a step behind those used for other offensive technologies. Arrowheads of flint and obsidian, knapped to remarkably uniform standards, survived well into the Bronze Age, and bronze arrowheads were used long after the adoption of iron for virtually every other military cutting or piercing implement.</p><!--[P53]--><p>Arrow shafts were made of relatively inexpensive wood and reed throughout history, though considerable labour was involved in shaping them. Remarkably refined techniques for fastening arrowheads of flint and obsidian to shafts were well in hand long before recorded history. (The importance of arrow <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/manufacturing" class="md-crosslink autoxref">manufacturing</a> techniques is reflected in the survival in modern English of the given name Fletcher, the title of a specialist in attaching feathers to the arrow shaft.)</p><!--[P54]--></section></section></section><section id="ref57581" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2"><span id="ref521918"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/artillery" class="md-crosslink">Mechanical artillery</a></h2><p>In contrast to individual weaponry, there was little continuity from classical to medieval times in mechanical artillery. The only exception—and it may have been a case of independent reinvention—was the similarity of the Roman <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/onager-weapon" class="md-crosslink autoxref">onager</a> to the medieval <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/catapult-military-weaponry" class="md-crosslink autoxref">catapult</a>.</p><!--[P55]--><p>Mechanical artillery of classical times was of two types: tension and torsion. In the first, energy to drive the projectile was provided by the tension of a drawn bow; in the other, it was provided by torsional energy stored in bundles of twisted fibres.</p><!--[P56]--><p>The <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/invention-technology" class="md-crosslink autoxref">invention</a> of mechanical artillery was ascribed traditionally to the <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/initiative" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="initiative">initiative</a> of <span id="ref521919"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Dionysius-I" class="md-crosslink">Dionysius</a> I, tyrant of Syracuse, in Sicily, who in 399 <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span> directed his <span id="ref521920"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/engine-ancient-warfare" class="md-crosslink">engineers</a> to construct military engines in preparation for war with Carthage. Dionysius’ engineers surely drew on existing practice. The earliest of the Greek engines was the <em><span id="ref521921"></span>gastrophetes</em>, or “belly shooter.” In effect a large <span id="ref521922"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/crossbow" class="md-crosslink">crossbow</a>, it received its name because the user braced the stock against his belly to draw the weapon. Though Greek texts did not go into detail on construction of the bow, it was based on a composite bow of wood, horn, and sinew. The potential of such engines was apparent, and the demand for greater power and range quickly exceeded the capabilities of tension. By the middle of the 3rd century <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span>, the bow had been replaced by rigid wooden arms constrained in a wooden box and drawn against the force of tightly twisted bundles of hair or sinew. The overall concept was similar to the <em>gastrophetes</em>, but the substitution of torsion for tension permitted larger and more powerful engines to be made. Such <span id="ref521923"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/catapult-military-weaponry" class="md-crosslink">catapults</a> (from Greek <em>kata</em>, “to pierce,” and <em>pelte</em>, “shield”; a “shield piercer”) could throw a javelin as far as 800 yards (700 metres). The same basic principle was applied to large stone-throwing engines. The Jewish historian Josephus referred to Roman catapults used in the siege of Jerusalem in <span class="text-smallcaps">ad</span> 70 that could throw a one-talent stone (about 55 pounds, or 25 kilograms) two <em>stades</em> (400 yards) or more.</p><!--[P57]--><p>The terminology of mechanical artillery is confusing. Catapult is the general term for mechanical artillery; however, the term also narrowly applies to a particular type of torsion engine with a single arm rotating in a vertical plane. Torsion engines with two horizontally opposed arms rotating in the horizontal plane, such as that described above, are called <span id="ref521924"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/ballista" class="md-crosslink">ballistae</a>. There is no evidence that catapults in the narrow sense were used by the Greeks; the Romans called their catapults <span id="ref521925"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/onager-weapon" class="md-crosslink">onagers</a>, or wild asses, for the way in which their rears kicked upward under the recoil force. The Romans used large ballistae and onagers effectively in siege operations, and a complement of <em><span id="ref521926"></span>carroballistae</em>, small, wheel-mounted torsion engines, was a regular part of the legion. The onager and the medieval catapult were identical in concept, but ballistae were not used after the classical era.</p><!--[P58]--></section><section id="ref57582" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2"><span id="ref521927"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/fortification" class="md-crosslink">Fortification</a></h2><span id="ref57582" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref57583" data-level="3"><h2 class="h3"><span id="ref521928"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/military-architecture" class="md-crosslink">Fortress design</a></h2><p>Fortifications in antiquity were designed primarily to defeat attempts at escalade, though cover was provided for archers and javelin throwers along the ramparts and for enfilade <span id="ref521929"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/fire-weaponry" class="md-crosslink">fire</a> from flanking towers. By classical Greek times, fortress <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/architecture" class="md-crosslink autoxref">architecture</a> had attained a high level of sophistication; both the profile and trace (that is, the height above ground level and the outline of the walls) of fortifications were designed to achieve overlapping fields of fire from ballistae mounted along the ramparts and in supporting towers. Roman fortresses of the 2nd century <span class="text-smallcaps">ad</span>, largely designed for logistic and administrative convenience, tended to have square or rectangular outlines, and were situated along major communication routes. By the late 3rd century, their walls had become thicker and had flanking towers strengthened to support mechanical artillery. The number of gates was reduced, and the ditches were dug wider. By the late 4th and 5th centuries, Roman fortresses were being built on easily defensible ground with irregular outlines that conformed to the topography; clearly, passive defense had become the dominant design consideration.</p><!--[P59]--><p>In general, the quality of masonry that went into permanent defensive works of the classical period was very high by later standards. Fortifications were almost exclusively of dressed stone, though by Roman times concrete <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/mortar-weapon" class="md-crosslink autoxref">mortar</a> was used on occasion.</p><!--[P60]--></section><span id="ref57582" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref57584" data-level="3"><h2 class="h3"><span id="ref521930"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/field-fortification" class="md-crosslink">Field fortification</a></h2><p>The main purpose of early field fortifications, particularly among the Greeks, was to secure an advantage by standing on higher ground so that the enemy was forced to attack uphill. The Romans were especially adept at field fortifications, preparing fortified camps at the close of each day’s march. The troops usually required three to four hours to dig a ditch around the <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/periphery" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="periphery">periphery</a>, erect a rampart or palisade from timbers carried by each man, lay out streets, and pitch tents. During extended campaigns the Romans strengthened the camps with towers and outlying redoubts, or small forts, and used the camps as bases for offensive forays into the surrounding territory.</p><!--[P61]--></section><span id="ref57582" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref57585" data-level="3"><h2 class="h3"><span id="ref521932"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/siege-tower" class="md-crosslink">Siege towers</a></h2><p>For <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/breaching" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="breaching">breaching</a> fortified positions, military engineers of the classical age designed assault towers that remain a wonder to modern engineers. So large was one <span id="ref521931"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/siege" class="md-crosslink">siege</a> tower used by Macedonians in an attack on Rhodes that 3,400 men were required to move it up to the city walls. Another 1,000 men were needed to wield a <a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/battering-ram" class="md-crosslink autoxref">battering ram</a> 180 feet (55 metres) long. The Romans constructed huge siege towers, one of which Caesar mentions as being 150 feet high. The lower stories housed the battering ram, which had either a pointed head for breaching or a ramlike head for battering. Archers in the upper stories shot arrows to drive the defenders from their ramparts. From the top of the tower, a hinged bridge might be lowered to serve a storming party. To guard the attackers against enemy missiles, the Romans used great wicker or wooden shields, called mantelets, which were sometimes mounted on wheels. In some cases the attackers might approach the fortress under the protection of wooden galleries.</p><!--[P62]--></section></section><section id="ref57586" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2"><span id="ref521933"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/land-transportation" class="md-crosslink">Land transportation</a></h2><p>In antiquity and classical times the <span id="ref521934"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/military-transportation" class="md-crosslink">transportation</a> technology of land warfare largely amounted to man’s own powers of locomotion. This was due in part to limitations in the size, strength, and stamina of horses and in part to deficiencies in crucial supporting technologies, notably the inefficiency of harnesses for horses and nonpivoting front axles for wagons. A more basic underlying factor was the generally low level of economic development. The horse was an economically inefficient animal, consuming large quantities of food. Of more importance, keeping horses—let alone selectively breeding them for size, strength, and power—was a highly labour-intensive and capital-intensive enterprise for which the classical world was not organized. An efficient pulling harness for horses was unknown, and mules and donkeys fitted with carrying baskets, or panniers, balanced in pairs across the back, were the most common pack or dray animals. The ox, the heavy-duty dray animal of the Mediterranean world, was used for military purposes when heavy loads were involved and speed was not critical.</p><!--[P63]--><span id="ref57586" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref57587" data-level="3"><h2 class="h3">The <span id="ref521935"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/animal/horse" class="md-crosslink">horse</a></h2><p>Because it was not possible to maintain a breed of war-horses sufficiently powerful to sustain mounted shock action, the horse was restricted to a subsidiary role in warfare from the eclipse of the chariot in the middle of the 2nd millennium <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span> until the rise of the horse archer in the 4th century <span class="text-smallcaps">ad</span>. Evidence as to the size of horses in classical times is <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/equivocal" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="equivocal">equivocal</a>. Greek vase paintings from the 7th century <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span> depict Scythians riding tall, apparently powerful horses with long, slender legs, implying speed; however, this breed evidently collapsed and disappeared. Later Mongolian steppe ponies, though tough and tractable, were probably considerably smaller.</p><!--[P64]--><p>Horses were rarely if ever used for drayage. This was partly because their rarity and expense restricted them to combat roles, and partly because of the lack of a suitable harness. The prevalent harness consisted of a pole-and-yoke assembly, attached to the animal by neck and chest harness. This was developed for use with oxen, where the primary load was absorbed by the thrust of the animal’s hump against the yoke. With a horse, most of the pulling load was borne by the neck strap, which tended to strangle the horse and constrict blood flow.</p><!--[P65]--></section><span id="ref57586" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref57588" data-level="3"><h2 class="h3">The <span id="ref521936"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/animal/elephant-mammal" class="md-crosslink">elephant</a></h2><p>The war elephant was first used in India and was known to the Persians by the 4th century <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span>. Though they accomplished little subsequently, their presence in Hannibal’s army during its transit of the Alps into Italy in 218 <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span> underscored their perceived utility. The elephant’s tactical importance apparently stemmed in large part from its willingness to charge both men and horses and from the panic that it inspired in horses.</p><!--[P66]--></section><span id="ref57586" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref57589" data-level="3"><h2 class="h3">The <span id="ref521937"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/technology/chariot" class="md-crosslink">chariot</a></h2><p>The chariot was the earliest means of transportation in combat other than man’s own powers of locomotion. The earliest known chariots, shown in <span id="ref521938"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Sumer" class="md-crosslink">Sumerian</a> depictions from about 2500 <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span>, were not true chariots but four-wheeled carts with solid wooden wheels drawn by a team of four donkeys or wild asses. They were no doubt heavy and cumbersome; lacking a pivoting front axle, they would have skidded through turns.</p><!--[P67]--><p>Around 1600 <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span> <span id="ref521939"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Iran" class="md-crosslink">Iranian</a> tribes introduced the war-horse into Mesopotamia from the north, along with the light two-wheeled chariot. The Hyksos apparently introduced the chariot into Egypt shortly thereafter, by which time it was a mature technology. By the middle of the 2nd millennium <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span>, Egyptian, Hittite, and Palestinian chariots were extraordinarily light and flexible vehicles, the wheels and tires in particular exhibiting great sophistication in design and fabrication. Light war chariots were drawn by either two or three horses, which were harnessed by means of chest girths secured by one or two poles and a yoke.</p><!--[P68]--><p>That horses were long used for pulling chariots rather than for riding is probably attributable to the horse’s inadequate strength and incomplete domestication. The chariot was subject to mechanical failure and, more importantly, was immobilized when any one of its horses was incapacitated. Moreover, the art of riding astride in cavalry fashion had been mastered long before the chariot’s eclipse as a tactically dominant weapon. The decline of the chariot by the end of the 2nd millennium <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span> was probably related to the spread of iron weaponry, but it was surely related also to the breeding of horses with sufficient strength and stamina to carry an armed man. Chariots lingered in areas of slower technological advance, but in the classical world they were retained mainly for ceremonial functions.</p><!--[P69]--></section></section></section><nav class="prev-next-pagination margin-top-50 margin-bottom-50 grid no-gutter  has-next">        <div class="pagination-control pagination-panel grid-xs ">                    </div>                    <div class="pagination-content pagination-panel grid-xs-shrink text-center text-uppercase">                Page 1 of 3            </div>                <div class="pagination-control pagination-panel text-right grid-xs has-link">                            <a href="/technology/military-technology/The-age-of-cavalry-c-ad-400-1350" class="next grid no-gutter">                    <div class="grid-xs" data-layout="column">                        <small class="pagination-control-label text-uppercase">Next page</small>                        <span class="pagination-control-description text-ellipsis" title="The age of cavalry, c. ad 400–1350">The age of cavalry, c. ad 400–1350</span>                    </div>                    <i class="material-icons md-36 grid-xs-shrink middle-xs" data-icon="keyboard_arrow_right"></i>                </a>                    </div>    </nav></article><div class="md-learn-more extra-content" data-module="learn-more" data-value="learn-more">        <h2>Learn More <span>in these related Britannica articles:</span></h2>        <ul>        <li class="entry">                <a href="/technology/small-arm">                    <div class="image-wrapper text-center">                            				<img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/180x300/96/176196-004-8B1EC116.jpg"  alt="semiautomatic pistol" />	</div>                    <div class="title"><strong>small arm</strong></div>                    <div class="description"><e ty="b">Small arm</e>,  any handheld firearm.
